Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:

Principal Investigator: Kevin D. Dorfman
University/Institution: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities

CAREER: Dynamics of DNA during Electrophoresis in Artificial Sieving Matrices

This project involves theoretical modeling and experimental investigation of microfluidic electrophoresis of DNA. DNA electrophoresis remains not only one of the most important tools in molecular biology and genetics, but also an ideal platform for testing fundamental theories of polymer dynamics and coarse-grained averaging of separation processes. The proposed research will address topics relevant to polymer physics, stochastic processes, and chemical engineering, working across multiple length scales to connect microscopic motion to macroscopic observables. The research component is an integrated theoretical and experimental program that addresses a range of fundamental issues arising during DNA separations in microfabricated post arrays, including the hindered relaxation phenomena in an external field and the role of the order of the post lattice. The research focuses on effects that arise from the proximity of posts in real separation devices, which are not addressed by the existing body of knowledge on DNA collisions with a single, isolated post. The experimental work spans multiple scales, combining ensemble-averaged measurements of the transport over several millimeters with detailed single-molecule observations of the local transport at the macromolecular scale. The microscopic insights will be used to construct new theoretical models, based upon continuous-time random walk theory, that rationalize the ensemble-averaged experimental results and predict new behavior that can be tested experimentally. In addition to training graduate students, the education component of this proposal consists of three parts: (i) developing a new course on the theory of electrophoresis and lab-on-a-chip technology; (ii) summer research opportunities for underrepresented minorities through a collaborative outreach program with the University of Puerto Rico at Mayaguez; and (iii) a K-12 outreach program with Edison High School in Minneapolis.
Most importantly, the research will link theory to experiment in a well-defined microstructured environment. The proposed work will lead to improved DNA separation devices, suitable for applied and fundamental research. Artificial matrices are poised to replace pulsed-field gel electrophoresis for important applications in genome mapping and DNA fingerprinting, but the incomplete understanding of the dynamics of DNA in artificial matrices has prevented this technique from moving beyond the proof-of-principle stage and into routine use. The fundamental results could also impact related separation techniques, such as electrochromatography and microfluidic HPLC. The summer research program with the University of Puerto Rico at Mayaguez will provide advanced training in computational and experimental techniques that are unavailable to these students at their home university. The outreach program with Edison High School in Minneapolis will integrate the research activities with education at the K-12 level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electrophoresis is the standard method for separating a mixture of DNA by size. In molecular biology, electrophoresis is used on a daily basis to identify the product of biochemical reactions or acquire genomic information. The most common medium for electrophoresis is an agarose gel. The randomly arranged pores in an agarose gel are several hundred microns in size (25,400 microns = 1 inch) and appropriately sized for separating relatively short DNA under a constant electric field. Such separations fail for long DNA, tens of thousands of base pairs or longer, because these large molecules are forced to uncoil inside the gel and slither along in the direction of the electric field. It is possible to separate long DNA molecules in an agarose gel by periodically changing the direction of the electric field, a method known as “pulsed field gel electrophoresis.” The limitation of pulsed field gel electrophoresis is that the DNA are forced to take a zig-zag path through the gel and spend much of their time stuck in place after the electric field switches direction. As a result, separating long DNA such as chromosomes, can take hours to days. 

Microfabrication has provided a new approach to develop separation media for long DNA. Using tools from the semiconductor industry, it is now possible to fabricate artificial sieving matrices in silicon dioxide consisting of a periodic arrangement of cylindrical posts. The post diameter and the spacing between posts are commensurate with the equilibrium size of the coiled, long DNA molecules. As a result, the DNA no longer need to uncoil to move through the array. Rather, the DNA move through the matrix in a relaxed conformation. The separation is effected by occasional collisions with the posts, where the DNA unravel and unhook from the post in a manner analogous to a rope-over-pulley. Since the nominal holdup time for a rope of length L is proportional to its length, different sized DNA are hooked on the post for a different duration. Although it has been known for almost 10 years that devices consisting of post arrays could reduce the separation time down to minutes or even seconds, the basic physical principles underlying the separation remained elusive. Without such design rules, it is impossible for engineers to optimize these promising separation devices.  

The most critical outcome of this research program was a thorough understanding of the role of the electric field on the separation process. Agarose gels are porous hydrogels, so the electric field inside a gel is uniform in space. In other words, DNA electrophoresis through an agarose gel is similar to the DNA “falling” through the agarose gel and occasionally hitting the fibers. The post arrays are constructed in electrically insulating materials, such as silicon dioxide. The material properties cause the electric field lines to curve around the posts in the array. The resulting dynamics look more like the DNA is slaloming down a ski slope rather than simply falling through the array. The Dorfman group at the University of Minnesota showed that the curved field lines invalidated the conclusions drawn from the existing theoretical models for DNA electrophoresis in a post array, which assumed the electric field was uniform in space. Importantly, they were able to demonstrate that separations are possible in sparse, ordered arrays of posts due to the curvature of the electric field. The latter systems are relatively simple and inexpensive to fabricate.

In addition to the fundamental breakthrough on the usefulness of post arrays, the Dorfman group at the University of Minnesota also developed the theoretical tools required to design post arrays for enhanced separations of long DNA.
